repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: James Applewhite is a poet and professor emeritus of English at Duke University. The collection is comprised of manuscripts, drafts, and proofs of poems, as well as notes, correspondence, clippings, and printed materials (including serials and anthologies). The collection documents Applewhite's work as a poet and professor of English at Duke University, including his research about Wordsworth. Manuscripts in the collection include Lessons in Soaring: Poems, A History of the River: Poems, and River Writing: An Eno Journal.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is restricted. Written permission is required to view correspondence and business records. Contact Research Services with questions.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], James Applewhite Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The James Applewhite Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 1993 and 2010.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.
Accessions included in this collection: 1993-0285 and 2010-0155

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: James W. Applewhite is a poet and professor emeritus of English at Duke University. He has published several books, including Statues of the Grass (1975), Following Gravity (1980), Foreseeing the Journey (1983), Seas and Inland Journeys: Landscape and Consciousness from Wordsworth to Roethke (1985), River Writing: An Eno Journal (1988), Lessons in Soaring (1989), Daytime and Starlight (1997), Selected Poems (2005), and A Diary of Altered Light (2006).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of manuscripts, drafts, and proofs of poems, as well as notes, correspondence, clippings, and printed materials (including serials and anthologies). The collection documents Applewhite's work as a poet and professor of English at Duke University, including his research about Wordsworth. Manuscripts in the collection include Lessons in Soaring: Poems, A History of the River: Poems, and River Writing: An Eno Journal.
There is no boxlist for this accession. Access is RESTRICTED: Written permission is required to view correspondence and business records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence files, writings (both published materials and drafts), photographs, biographical/bibliographical lists and files, and other miscellaneous materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence with literary figures and publishers. Frequent correspondents include Dave Smith, Donald Hall, Dabney Stuart, Fred Chappell, Robert Bly, James Dickey, Michael McFee, Gibbons Ruark, and others. Also includes 1 folder of Pulitzer Prize jury correspondence. This material has been loosely arranged into folders by year, but has not been sorted by date within each folder.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: This material may be RESTRICTED. Contact Research Services with questions.

did.unittitle: Loose poetry sent and received, dates unknown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly consists of loose poetry and other manuscripts. Includes manuscript drafts for "Following Gravity," "Iron Age Flying," "A Journal of Sunlight," "Steps to the Stream," "Driving through the Country America that is Vanishing," "Landmind," "Gift of Inheritance and Other Poems," as well as some drafts of essays and articles. Other materials include Applewhite's notebooks and notepads, many with poetry or drafts, as well as some with notes, schedules, to-do lists, and other miscellaneous writings.

did.unittitle: Driving through the Country America that is Vanishing, 1973 and undated (3 folders)
Gift of Inheritance and Other Poems, undated
Unpublished novel: Alive in Time, undated (3 folders)
Driving through the Country America that is Vanishing, undated (2 folders)
Legal notepads with drafts and ideas (10 folders)
Notepads with drafts and ideas, 1988-1991 and undated (3 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes Applewhite's research files and some research papers, his applications for various fellowships, and recommendations he wrote for his students. Also includes biographical and bibliographical details, photographs, newspaper clippings, and magazine addresses.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: This material may be RESTRICTED. Contact Research Services with questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes writings (both published materials and drafts), professional materials (including photographs, information about events, & awards and honors), correspondence -primarily with publishers and journal editors, extensive notes, and other miscellaneous materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains drafts and notes related to Applewhite's writings. There are a number of legal and notepads containing drafts of both poems and prose works, as well as letters. The materials include voluminous notes and drafts for Applewhite's Cosmos and Creation. The series has been organized into two subseries: one for prose and one for poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes various handwritten and typed notes by Applewhite. The notes pertain to Applewhite's academic career, teaching, writing and planning, and drafts of correspondence. There are also several lists of addresses and contacts. Many of the notes are in legalpads, spiral notebooks, and small bound notebooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Applewhite's own published works, including manuscripts, reviews, and advice from other authors.

did.unittitle: Draft & Response for "American-Type" Painting & Poetry in the 1950's
A Long Poem: Published in Crazy Horse (1992), Three Poems: Published in Carolina Quarterly (1966)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series includes Applewhite's letters to publishers, acceptance and rejection letters, submission lists, and miscellaneous correspondence with colleagues and friends from approximately 1980-2008. Publication related to specific works is labeled as such, with the rest of the series organized by year.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Correspondence and business records are restricted for the life of the donor. Contact Research Services for details.

did.unittitle: Publication Correspondence Re: The Human Style
Publication Correspondence Re: A History of the River
Publication Correspondence Re: Lessons in Soaring
Publication Correspondence Re: Quartet for Three Voices

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The professional series contains materials related to Applewhite's academic and literary career. These materials include interviews, photos, biographies of Applewhite (by himself and by others), grant applications and notes, information on events attended, and awards and honors.
